name: Aluminum
notes: Most common plate material, can be pingy without dampening.
compatibilityNotes: Universal fit for most builds.

name: Polycarbonate (PC)
notes: Popular for a softer, flexier typing experience.
compatibilityNotes: May not be available for all layouts; check vendor listings.

name: FR4
notes: Popular mid-range option with a neutral sound signature.
compatibilityNotes: Widely available; same PCB material so pairs well structurally.

name: Brass
notes: Heavy and premium-feeling, pingy without dampening.
compatibilityNotes: Adds significant weight; not ideal for portable builds.

name: POM
notes: Self-lubricating material, smooth typing feel.
compatibilityNotes: Less common; check compatibility with your case and PCB.

name: Aluminum
notes: Needs foam to tame resonance; most popular premium option.
compatibilityNotes: Heavy; most custom kits use aluminum cases.

name: Polycarbonate
notes: See-through for RGB lighting; warmer sound profile.
compatibilityNotes: Great for RGB builds; can yellow over time with UV exposure.

name: Plastic/ABS
notes: Budget-friendly; hollow sound without internal dampening.
compatibilityNotes: Common in prebuilt keyboards; benefits greatly from mods.

name: Wood
notes: Niche material with a distinctive warm sound and look.
compatibilityNotes: Very limited availability; often custom or artisan builds only.

name: Cherry
notes: Low profile, most popular, comfortable for long sessions.
compatibilityNotes: Compatible with virtually all MX-style switches and layouts.

name: SA
notes: Tall, sculpted, retro look; deeper sound due to larger keycap cavity.
compatibilityNotes: Taller profile may interfere with low-profile cases; check clearance.

name: MT3
notes: Similar to SA but more ergonomic with scooped tops.
compatibilityNotes: Same clearance considerations as SA profile.

name: DSA
notes: Uniform, flat profile; easy to rearrange keys between rows.
compatibilityNotes: Works well with ortholinear and non-standard layouts.

name: KAT
notes: Medium height with a smooth feel; good all-rounder.
compatibilityNotes: Compatible with most standard and non-standard layouts.

name: PBT
notes: Textured, durable, doesn't develop shine over time.
compatibilityNotes: Available in most profiles; some color limitations with dyesub legends.

name: ABS
notes: Smoother feel, can develop shine over time with use.
compatibilityNotes: Supports doubleshot legends with excellent clarity; widely available.

name: POM
notes: Rare material; very smooth surface with a distinctive sound.
compatibilityNotes: Limited availability; usually only in Cherry or uniform profiles.

name: Gasket Mount
notes: Most sought-after mounting style; soft, bouncy typing feel.
compatibilityNotes: Requires gaskets between plate and case; most mid-to-high-end customs use this.

name: Top Mount
notes: Plate screws into the top of the case; stiffer and louder.
compatibilityNotes: Common in mid-range customs; straightforward assembly.

name: Tray Mount
notes: Budget standard; most hollow and pingy without mods.
compatibilityNotes: Most common in prebuilt and entry-level custom keyboards.

name: Sandwich Mount
notes: Plate sandwiched between top and bottom case layers.
compatibilityNotes: Common in acrylic or stacked builds; simpler construction.

name: Leaf Spring / O-ring
notes: Very soft and bouncy typing experience; niche but loved.
compatibilityNotes: Found in specific high-end boards; not interchangeable with other mount types.

name: PE Foam Sheet
notes: Placed between PCB and switches; gives a poppy, marble-like sound.
compatibilityNotes: Must be cut to fit PCB layout; may affect switch seating on hotswap boards.

name: Tape Mod (Tempest)
notes: Layers of tape on the back of the PCB to deepen the sound profile.
compatibilityNotes: Works on any PCB; use painter's tape to avoid residue.

name: Case Foam
notes: Foam placed inside the case to reduce empty-space resonance.
compatibilityNotes: Must be cut to fit; avoid blocking PCB components or screw posts.

name: Switch Films
notes: Thin films placed between switch top and bottom housings for a tighter fit.
compatibilityNotes: Not needed on switches with already tight tolerances; may prevent closure on some switches.

name: Holee Mod (stabilizers)
notes: Band-aid or fabric placed inside stabilizer stems to eliminate rattle.
compatibilityNotes: Works on Cherry-style screw-in and plate-mount stabilizers.

name: Band-Aid Mod (stabilizers)
notes: Small fabric bandage pads placed on PCB under stabilizers to cushion bottom-out.
compatibilityNotes: Best used with PCB-mount stabilizers; less effective with plate-mount.

name: Lubing Switches (Krytox 205g0)
notes: Hand-lubing switches with Krytox 205g0 for a smooth, premium sound and feel.
compatibilityNotes: Use 205g0 for linears; consider lighter lubes (3203/3204) for tactiles to preserve bump.

name: Lubing Stabilizers (Dielectric Grease)
notes: Dielectric grease on stabilizer wires to eliminate rattle and ticking.
compatibilityNotes: Apply to wire ends and contact points; works on all Cherry-style stabilizers.

name: Spring Swap
notes: Swap stock springs for custom weights to customize actuation force.
compatibilityNotes: Most MX-style switches accept standard springs; check spring length for long-pole switches.

name: O-Ring Dampeners
notes: Rubber rings placed on keycap stems; not recommended by enthusiasts as they create a mushy feel.
compatibilityNotes: Fits any MX-compatible keycap stem; reduces travel distance.

name: Polyfill / Stuffing
soundEffect: fills empty case space, reduces hollowness
notes: Polyester stuffing placed in the case cavity to absorb sound and reduce hollowness.
compatibilityNotes: Works in any case with empty space; avoid overpacking to prevent PCB flex.

name: Force Break Mod
notes: Reduces direct contact between plate and case for increased flex and a softer typing feel.
compatibilityNotes: Most effective on top-mount and tray-mount boards; gasket-mount boards already isolate the plate.
